And the more you look at the current landscape, the harder it is to dismiss. The UFC has no clear parameters for when a champion must defend. Boxing does. Pro wrestling used to. Even other sports have timelines. But at heavyweight, we‚Äôre operating without a clock. Tom Aspinall is the undisputed champion, injured in the Octagon, and that matters. If anyone deserves patience, it‚Äôs him. This isn‚Äôt about stripping Tom. It‚Äôs about keeping the division moving while he heals. The problem is clarity. We don‚Äôt know how long Aspinall will be out, and we don‚Äôt know what the plan is. Holding everything for a Ciryl Gane rematch might sound logical, but timing matters. That first fight was the lowest-performing pay-per-view of the year, and momentum fades fast. Waiting another four or five months doesn‚Äôt help anyone‚Äîespecially the rest of the division. Here‚Äôs the bigger issue: who exactly would even fight for an interim belt? Interim titles usually exist to justify massive, unavoidable fights. At heavyweight, that fight doesn‚Äôt obviously exist. Outside of a handful of names‚Äîand one undefeated wrestler, Josh Hockett‚Äîthe division is thin. Wrestling, the most dominant skill set in MMA history, is nearly absent at heavyweight right now. Waldo‚Äôs idea isn‚Äôt wrong. It‚Äôs just incomplete. An interim belt only works if there‚Äôs a fight worthy of it. And that‚Äôs the question nobody‚Äôs answering. Brown came out and said he wouldn‚Äôt pick Paddy Pimblett against anyone in the top 10‚Äîand maybe not even 11 or 12. That‚Äôs a strong statement, and it deserves a closer look. Yes, Paddy didn‚Äôt look great in that fight. Nobody‚Äôs arguing that. But judging a fighter‚Äôs entire ceiling off one performance‚Äîespecially their first five-round, title-level main event‚Äîis dangerous. MMA changes when you change the rules. And that raises a question the UFC has never answered clearly: how do the rankings actually work? Rakhmonov was undefeated, dominant, and consistently ranked near the top. Then suddenly‚Äîhe‚Äôs gone. The explanation floating around is injury, with his manager Danny Rubenstein confirming knee surgery that could keep him out for most of the year. This isn‚Äôt about conspiracies. It‚Äôs about transparency. If a fighter doesn‚Äôt move down, but instead vanishes entirely, someone made that call. articles.title: Retirement? Volkanovski Said No Chance #ufc
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski doesn‚Äôt just fight ‚Äî he outworks you, outlasts you, and somehow finds a way. Every single time. Chael Sonnen breaks down what makes Volk different. Winning one gritty fight takes heart. Doing it over and over for years? That takes a lifetime of work. And now, Volkanovski is tying Jos√© Aldo‚Äôs legendary featherweight record, putting himself in rare air among the greatest 145-pounders ever. For a moment, it felt like this might be the end. His tone was calm. Almost reflective. Like a guy who might be ready to hang them up. And honestly, if Volk had retired, nobody would‚Äôve questioned it. He‚Äôs earned that right. But then he did the opposite. Instead of walking away, Volkanovski called out Movsar Evloev and Lerone Murphy ‚Äî two of the toughest, hungriest contenders in the division. No easy fights. No victory laps. Just straight back into the fire. That tells you everything. Chael explains why that mentality separates champions from legends. Some guys protect their legacy. Volk keeps testing it. He‚Äôs not chasing comfort ‚Äî he‚Äôs chasing competition. Retirement doesn‚Äôt sound like a man calling out killers. This isn‚Äôt the end. It might be another run. #AlexanderVolkanovski #UFC #MMA #JoseAldo #MovsarEvloev #LeroneMurphy #Featherweight #ChaelSonnen

articles.title: Volk Could‚Äôve Been Double Champ #ufc
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski was closer to becoming a double champion than people remember ‚Äî and Chael Sonnen thinks he might have actually beaten Islam Makhachev that first night. Not ‚Äúcompetitive.‚Äù Not ‚Äúmoral victory.‚Äù Chael means flat-out won. In this breakdown, Chael revisits their first lightweight title fight and explains why Volk‚Äôs performance ages better every single time we watch Islam dominate the division. Makhachev is breaking records, running through contenders, even flirting with welterweight ‚Äî and we‚Äôre supposed to forget that Volkanovski pushed him to the absolute limit? Volk clearly won two rounds. Some argue three. And when the decision came in, nobody felt certain. That‚Äôs how close it was. But here‚Äôs Chael‚Äôs key point: commitment. If Volkanovski had fully relinquished the 145-pound belt and truly moved up to 155 ‚Äî bigger camp, bigger body, fully adjusted ‚Äî maybe that tiny gap disappears. Maybe that razor-close fight flips. Maybe we‚Äôre talking about ‚Äúchamp-champ‚Äù Volk right now. Instead, he tried to do both. And at the highest level, half-measures cost you inches ‚Äî and inches cost you titles. Looking back, it might be one of the biggest ‚Äúwhat ifs‚Äù in UFC history. #AlexanderVolkanovski #IslamMakhachev #UFC #MMA #DoubleChamp #Lightweight #Featherweight #chaelsonnen

articles.title: Volk Isn‚Äôt Done Yet ‚Äî His Coach Says Four More Fights
articles.description: The retirement talk around Alexander Volkanovski doesn‚Äôt match reality ‚Äî and his coach just made that clear. After the fight, Volkanovski‚Äôs coach spoke openly about camp, injuries, and the future, including a shoulder issue serious enough that they considered pulling out of the fight. This wasn‚Äôt adrenaline or hype. It was an honest assessment, and it came with a surprising statement: they believe Volkanovski still has four more fights in him. In this breakdown, Chael Sonnen explains why the idea of Volkanovski retiring now doesn‚Äôt add up. Yes, he‚Äôs fought at home. Yes, he‚Äôs broken records. Yes, he‚Äôs cemented his legacy. But Volkanovski has also been transparent about something else ‚Äî free time is not good for him. He needs structure, goals, and competition. Walking away doesn‚Äôt solve that. Great champions face this moment differently. Some leave on top, like Khabib Nurmagomedov. Others keep competing because that‚Äôs who they are. Volkanovski fits the second category. The most important part? The gap. One judge scored the fight five rounds to none. Volkanovski could fight worse than he did Saturday and still be better than the rest of the division. That level of separation is rare ‚Äî and it means retirement isn‚Äôt imminent. Four fights doesn‚Äôt sound crazy. It sounds realistic. articles.title: Chael Defends Tai Tuivasa After a Brutal Night
articles.description: When Chael Sonnen calls someone ‚Äúterrible,‚Äù it isn‚Äôt always an insult. In this breakdown, Chael explains why Tai Tuivasa embodies a rare quality that can‚Äôt be coached, drilled, or earned through belt levels: pure toughness. At heavyweight, Chael argues, there‚Äôs a point where skill acquisition hits a ceiling and fighters must operate within the limits of their bodies. Tai lives in that reality ‚Äî and embraces it. Chael compares Tuivasa to fighters like Derrick Lewis and even a modern-day Tank Abbott, emphasizing that Tai isn‚Äôt a technician off his back or a jiu-jitsu specialist. He‚Äôs a cage fighter. A street fighter. And that‚Äôs not a flaw ‚Äî it‚Äôs his identity. Despite questioning himself early in the fight and finding himself in bad positions, Tuivasa never chose the easy way out. Chael breaks down how many fighters quietly quit through positional surrender ‚Äî and why Tai simply doesn‚Äôt know how to do that. Instead, he fought through exhaustion, adversity, and doubt, finding his way back to his feet and back into the fight. Even in defeat, Chael believes Tuivasa discovered something important: he‚Äôs tougher, more competitive, and more capable than he realized. And in heavyweight MMA, that may be the rarest commodity of all.
